sn56.43:1.1: “Mendicants, there is a hell called ‘The Mighty Fever’.
sn56.43:1.2: There, whatever sight you see with your eye is unlikable, not likable; undesirable, not desirable; unpleasant, not pleasant.
sn56.43:1.3: Whatever sound you hear … Whatever odor you smell … Whatever flavor you taste …
sn56.43:1.5: Whatever thought you know with your mind is unlikable, not likable; undesirable, not desirable; unpleasant, not pleasant.”
sn56.43:2.1: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,
sn56.43:2.2: “Sir, that fever really is mighty, so very mighty.
sn56.43:2.3: Is there any other fever more mighty and terrifying than this one?”
sn56.43:3.2: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
sn56.43:3.3: They take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth …
sn56.43:3.4: They continue to make such choices …
sn56.43:3.5: Having made such choices, they burn with the fever of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.43:3.6: They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.43:3.7: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.
sn56.43:4.1: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
sn56.43:4.2: They don’t take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth …
sn56.43:4.4: Having stopped making such choices, they don’t burn with the fever of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.43:4.5: They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.43:4.6: They’re freed from suffering, I say.
sn56.43:5.1: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
